title: Royal New Zealand Foundation of the Blind
text:
The Royal New Zealand Foundation of the Blind, now known as Blind Foundation, is a provider of services to <a href="blindness">blind</a>, <a href="Deafblindness">deafblind</a> and <a href="vision%20impairment">vision-impaired</a> people in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>.
History.
The Foundation began in 1890 as the Jubilee Institute for the Blind with a school and residence in <a href="Parnell%2C%20Auckland">Parnell, Auckland</a>. <a href="Sheltered%20workshop">Sheltered workshop</a>s and <a href="hostel">hostel</a>s were provided for many years. These were phased out at the end of the twentieth century in favour of <a href="Mainstreaming%20%28education%29">mainstreaming</a>, members' greater integration into the community. A school run by the Foundation became part of the public school system.
The "Royal New Zealand Foundation of the Blind Act 2002" allows for the Foundation to become an incorporated society.
After a rebranding consultation process, the name of the Royal New Zealand Foundation of the Blind, changed to Blind Foundation in December 2013.
Services.
The Foundation website lists the following services:
<a href="counselling">counselling</a>, equipment, financial assistance, <a href="Volunteering">volunteer</a> assistance, mobility, <a href="guide%20dog">guide dog</a>s, <a href="employment">employment</a> assistance, <a href="peer%20support">peer support</a>, <a href="recreation">recreation</a>, <a href="Reading%20%28process%29">reading</a> and <a href="writing">writing</a> in <a href="audiobook">audio</a>, <a href="braille">braille</a> and other formats, library, Telephone Information Service, accessible formats (braille, audio, electronic text and large print), adaptive communications and technology. The foundation also did Braille checks for the video games <a href="Pok%C3%A9mon%20FireRed%20and%20LeafGreen">Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen</a> and is mentioned in the credits.
All of the foundation's funding comes from public donations.
